description:
Shocking Blue
Greatest Hits (2008)





Formed in 1967 by former Motions guitarist Robbie van Leeuwen, the Dutch quartet Shocking Blue originally had a lineup of VanLeeuwen on guitar, lead vocalist Fred DeWilde, bass player Klaasje Van der Wal, and drummer Cornelius Van der Beek, and the initial configuration of the band had a minor homeland hit with Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lucy Brown Is Back in TownÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ a year later in 1968. Things really got moving, though, when DeWilde was replaced by sultry singer Mariska Veres, whose sexy presence and solid singing brought the band a second Netherlands hit, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Send Me a Postcard,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ and then a huge international smash with Ã¢â‚¬Å“VenusÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ in 1970 after the group had signed to Jerry Ross' Colossus Records imprint. Although Shocking Blue's albums (1968Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Shocking Blue, 1969Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s At Home, 1970Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s ScorpioÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Dance, 1971Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s 3rd Album, 1972Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Inkpot, 1972Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Attila, 1973Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Dream on Dreamer, and 1974Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Good Times) featured progressive rock elements and inventive arrangements thanks to VanLeeuwen's writing and production skills, the band was essentially marketed as a pop singles unit, and while they scored several subsequent hits in their homeland, none of the groupÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s releases approached the massive saturation success of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Venus.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Veres left Shocking Blue in 1974 to pursue a solo career, and while there have been various reunions and different touring incarnations of the band over the years (including a version fronted by Veres in the '90s), its creative history ended then. VanLeeuwen later re-surfaced in the folk/jazz group Galaxy-Lin, while his most famous composition, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Venus,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ continued to see play on oldies stations. Veres died of cancer in 2006 at the age of 59.
